entry.title: Re: Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries
entry.content:
Very high retries or unlimited retries gives us flexibility in two scenarios.

1.To automatically resend the failed messages when target connection is resolved without manual intervention. This scenario is encountered during weekend maintenance downtimes of the connected systems. The backed-up messages in Integration layer will start flowing without manual retry.

2.When we are waiting for a change/fix to move to production then it should automatically process the failed message when the new fix is promoted to Production.

Yes, moving message to a dead letter queue is another technique but we were focusing on automatic reprocessing of messages for temp connection issue like downtimes or when Interface requires a quick emergency fix.

entry.title: ONB_ Crossboarding triggering in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0 for Internal Hires
entry.content:
Hi all,

We previously used ONB1.0 and have now moved to ONB2.0. We no longer want Crossboarding to trigger in ONB1.0, but when we initiate a transfer, it still triggers Crossboarding in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0. How do we prevent a record from being created in ONB1.0?

We currently have three Crossboarding rules, and they work correctly for ONB2.0. However, ONB1.0 continues to generate a record:

  1. Rule linked to Business Configuration > Job Information > Trigger Rules > OnPostSave

  2. EVENT_TRANSFER

  3. ONB2_InternalHire_Configuration rule (scenario: Initiate Internal Recruit Configuration)

As per KBA 3515053, if no rule exists with the ‚ÄúInitiate Internal Recruit Configuration‚Äù scenario, the system assumes the condition is true and creates a Crossboarding 1.0 record. The KBA suggests creating a rule for ONB1.0 with a condition that can never be true.

However, my tests show:

  • When the Initiate Internal Recruit Configuration rule evaluates to true, a CXB record is created in both ONB1.0 and ONB2.0.

  • When I add an impossible condition (so rule evaluates to false), a record is created in ONB1.0 only, and nothing in ONB2.0.

How can we fully stop ONB1.0 from generating a record, but creates only in ONB2.0?


We still have some users completing CXB in ONB1.0, so deactivating the process may not be a practical solution for some more time. Also, the KBA mentions  as a symptom that "disabling the Process Filter and Crossboarding Process in Super Admin did not help", which adds to the confusion.

Please let me know how to just trigger CXB for ONB2.0.

Regards,

Divia

@Gopinath_Murugaiyan

entry.title: Application Decisions for Sales Order Management in CX - Part 1
entry.content:
Summary

One of the key functions within the sales process is the creation of a Sales Order, typically followed by its replication to the back-office system (whether SAP ERP or SAP S/4HANA). This process, known as Sales Order Management, is part of the Lead-to-Cash enterprise process and is a common scenario across multiple industries.

The Sales Order Management (Customer > Sales > Customer Order and Contract Management) encompasses the entire customer order lifecycle, from order creation to fulfillment orchestration. It includes activities such as determining competitive pricing, checking real-time inventory availability, managing customer credit risk, transferring customer demand to downstream logistics processes, and monitoring overall order-fulfillment status.

This process leverages several components across both front-office and back-office applications and, in some cases, integration tools. Potential applications supporting this business capability include SAP Cloud for Customer or SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, and SAP S/4HANA Sales, integrated with the respective back-office systems.

The purpose of this document is to provide key decision criteria to help you, and your organization determine how best to support these business requirements within your target architecture. Most of the information presented here is publicly available through SAP channels such as the SAP Help Portal; however, it has been consolidated here for your convenience into a single, comprehensive reference.

This document has two parts: The first focuses on the functional and business aspects, and the second covers the technical details. At the end of the technical section, you‚Äôll find a conclusion that summarizes both parts.

Business Requirements

During the target solution definition, these are the business capabilities related to Sales Order Management mentioned in the Reference Business Architecture or RBA (part of the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework):

  • Sales Order Management: Ability to cover the full cycle of customer order processing, from multichannel order creation to fulfillment orchestration. It includes determining a competitive price, checking online inventory availability, managing customer credit risk, handing over customer demand to logistical follow-up processes, and tracking overall order-fulfillment status.
  • Customer Order Monitoring: Ability to monitor the execution of customer orders by checking and analyzing key operation-performance indicators. This includes raising attention to business exceptions and potential defects, for proactive prevention.

Solution Options

In the customer experience domain, two options could cover the giving capabilities (not including a back-office system):

  • SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud: Sales Orders
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2: Sales Orders

Note: Although SAP S/4HANA Sales manages sales orders lifecycle through its Order and Contract Management functionality, this document does not aim to describe or analyze those standard features.

Characterization of the Solution Options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), is SAP's on-demand cloud-based Customer Relationship Management, it consists of SAP Cloud for Sales and SAP Cloud for Services.

Sales Orders

In SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), the sales process starts with maintaining a product catalog that includes pricing and discount details. Sales representatives create quotes for interested customers, reusing data from existing opportunities and adding cross-sell products as needed.

Quotes undergo pricing, either within C4C or through integration with the back-office, SAP ERP/SAP S/4HANA, can follow an approval workflow before being sent to the customer.

Quotes are also part of the process: Once a quote is accepted, a sales order is created directly in C4C or as a follow-up in the back-office. Orders are synchronized across systems, ensuring visibility of delivery, invoicing, and fulfillment through the 360¬∞ Customer View.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is considered the next evolution of SAP C4C - Sales. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is designed to help sales teams manage their accounts, leads, opportunities, and activities. This version includes new features and improvements to help sales professionals improve their sales performance, streamline their processes, and provide better customer experiences.

Sales Orders

In SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, a Sales Order represents the agreement between the seller and customer regarding product delivery or service provision, including defined prices, quantities, and dates.

This flexibility allows organizations to handle both standalone and integrated sales order scenarios seamlessly.

Criteria to determine the most suitable target solution

Several aspects will determinate the best solution to handle Sales Orders in your architecture, here‚Äôs some of the most relevant ones related to the functional area:

1. Sales Order Types

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

C4C offers three different types of sales orders:

  • External and Internal: This is the default mode and allows sales order creation with bi-directional transfer of sales orders between SAP C4C and SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP. Example: A sales representative creates a sales order in SAP C4C while visiting a customer, the order is immediately replicated to SAP S/4HANA and updates from this system (such as delivery status, invoice number, or quantity changes), are sent back to C4C.
  • External Only: This mode supports Display Only of sales orders that are created in external system and displayed in the cloud solution. Example: A sales representative logs into SAP C4C and views an order that was created entirely in SAP S/4HANA by an e-commerce system.
  • Internal Only: This applies for the standalone scenario where these types of orders only exist within SAP C4C and do not support the price simulation or the use of back-office systems like SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP. The orders of this type can only be previewed, printed and sent by e-mail. Example: A sales representative creates a Sales Order that exists only in C4C and It cannot simulate prices.

Please refer to the SAP Help Portal Maintain Sales Order Document Types section for more details.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 enables users to manage and track all sales interactions related to orders vi the maintenance mode parameter as follows:

  • Internal & External: You can replicate sales orders and receive continuous updates on them from external SAP systems. You can create, replicate, and modify the sales orders with bidirectional data transfer between an external SAP system and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.
  • External: You can replicate sales orders from external SAP systems, but cannot edit the sales orders in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. In SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, you can only display these sales orders, which are created in external systems.
  • Internal: You can create and edit sales orders only in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

Visit the Configure Sales Orders section in the SAP Help Portal for more information.

2. Partner Determination

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

In C4C, you can configure the allowed involved parties at the sales order header and item level using determination rules and code list restrictions in the Determination of Involved Parties configuration. It is also possible to add parties manually as needed.

With the ‚ÄúTake Over Party Determination‚Äù function enabled, parties involved are copied or inherited from a predecessor document, for example, from a Sales Quote document, into the Sales Order.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 you can determine involved parties for business transactions using party roles and the connected determination rules and master data. 

For Sales Orders, you can configure all party role assignments in the ‚Äúparty schema‚Äú that handles both, party roles that can be internal and external involved parties. The party role selection can be controlled through Code List Restrictions as well.

3. Pricing

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP C4C typically uses standard pricing logic that is integrated to reflect the ERP pricing conditions. The settings allow it to replicate such conditions through various middleware, ensuring consistency with the pricing data from SAP ERP systems.

SAP C4C provides flexible internal, external, and offline pricing and pricing discounts in Sales Orders:

  • Internal Pricing (not integrated with SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP): For this you must maintain price lists and customer-specific price lists, along with discount lists and a single pricing procedure in the system. Internal pricing takes prices from the price list created by your administrator and can include optional predefined discounts.
    Additional features in the internal pricing option:
  • Allows price adjustments including action ‚ÄúUpdate Pricing‚Äù in the Pricing tab in the Sales Order (this tab appears only in maintenance mode ‚ÄúInternal‚Äù).
  • Edit List Price and Product Discount (%) in the Products table.
  • Edit Overall Discount (%) in the Overview.
  • External Pricing: Allows you to retrieve their complete price information including tax details from an external SAP system like SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA (keep in mind that your C4C system must be connected directly with the external system via a middleware).
    Pricing is obtained via a user action to retrieve the external pricing result and apply discounts or other price elements is the Sales Order if necessary.
    How external pricing is executed? External pricing is done through order simulation in the back-office system. The back-office system then simulates a complete document, and you receive the results in your quote or order.
  • Offline Pricing: In ‚Äúoffline mode‚Äù, you can calculate an estimated price value based on the price list existed in C4C (that could be synchronized from the back-office system), including a fixed or percentage-based discount for your Sales Order items created in offline.
    Sync the discount details when you are working online again. You can also view the external pricing result in offline mode.
    Extensibility: You can map extension fields created in your 'Z' space in SAP ERP with extension fields in your SAP C4C system and use them for offline pricing calculation.

More details available in the Create Sales Orders and Pricing sections of the SAP Help.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 builds upon advanced functionalities, providing more comprehensive and flexible pricing schemes, often leveraging enhanced analytical capabilities and AI-driven pricing strategies.

The solution offers two types of pricing:

  • Internal pricing (native pricing): The price is calculated using the pricing components and pricing master data defined in the system (not integrated with SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP).
  • External pricing: The complete price information including tax details is retrieved from an external SAP system. End-users request pricing via simulation in sales orders to retrieve the external pricing result and apply discounts or other pricing elements if necessary. You can also use the solution to determine credit limits and product availability information from simulation.

You can import pricing configurations from all SAP S/4HANA products to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 through automated integration. You can manually download pricing configurations from SAP ECC and upload them to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

For more information please check the Pricing section in the SAP Help Portal.

4. Master Data

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP C4C integrates with SAP back-office systems to fetch relevant master data required during the creation and processing of sales orders.

Master data synchronization ensures that information such as customer preferences, product availability, and pricing remains up-to-date throughout the sales order lifecycle.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

It provides an improved data model for managing customer relationships, product configurations, and order processing details.

Utilizes integrated analytics and AI-driven insights to streamline the sales order process, optimizing customer engagement and fulfillment.

5. Approvals

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

In SAP C4C, you can set different approval processes for sales orders before submitting for processing. Multiple approval levels are available as defined in the configuration.

If a Sales Order needs approval, you can use a workflow action called ‚ÄúSubmit Orders for Approval‚Äú where you can: Revoke, Submit for Approval, Transfer, and Withdraw from Approval.

You can see the approval process, history, and details under the Approvals tab. Automatic approval is also possible and approvals via E-Mail.

More details available at the Complete Sales Orders in the available documentation.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

The solution supports Sales Order‚Äôs approval workflows that send a notification to the corresponding approver. Approval conditions can be based on amount or price.

In terms of transporting approval rule changes to a production environment, Sales Cloud V2 offers greater flexibility. You can transport an individual approval rule without needing to move the entire change project, and the solution also supports versioning.

If you need more information, please refer to the Submit Sales Orders for Approval section in the SAP Help Portal.

6. Mobile App

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Cloud for Customer provides you with instant access to the solution data from a phone or tablet using the SAP Cloud for Customer Mobile Apps available for iPad, Android, and Windows Tablet.

Regarding the Sales Order processing, the Mobile App allows you to create and manage sales orders including:

  • Order Details
  • Line Items
  • Pricing
  • Fulfillment

In offline mode, several options are available including:

  • Product proposals
  • Promotions
  • Pricing (based on replicated conditions from ERP system)
  • Order validations like minimum order quantity

More information in the About Mobile Options section of the SAP help portal.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

The SAP Sales Cloud Mobile application provides you access to data in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and allows your sales teams to:

  • View Sales Orders
  • Create and manage Sales Orders
  • Create External Sales Orders
  • Simulate Sales Orders

There's no offline support for this application at the moment, but in recent upgrades for the iOS app, it was mentioned the possibility to enable Downloads for Offline Access. However, downloaded entities like Sales Orders are read only and can't be modified.

More information in the SAP Sales Cloud Mobile Application and the Downloads documentation.

7. Machine Learning and Generative AI

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

At the moment there‚Äôs no Machine Learning or Gen AI functionalities in SAP C4C related to the Sales Order Management processes.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Sales Order Summary: A Gen AI feature that automatically analyzes and presents insights from pricing simulations including.

  • Change in product pricing from the original price, provides insights about whether the price has increased or decreased and by what percentage.
  • On-time delivery of the products, whether the products are scheduled for on-time delivery or if delivery is delayed.
  • Products within the order are substituted with an alternative product.
  • The number of free products, based on the pricing arrangement.

For more details, please refer to the Sales Order Summary documentation.

Conclusion

The first part of this document concludes here, providing a functional view of Sales Order Management within SAP Customer Experience‚Äôs cloud solutions.

In the next part, we will focus on the technical aspects, including integrations and extensibility options. This section will conclude with a comparison of the two available solutions: SAP Cloud for Customer (Sales Cloud) and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Here‚Äôs the link for your convenience.

entry.title: The Secure Way to Migrate S/4HANA: Step-by-Step HANA Tenant Copy with SSL Encryption
entry.content:
As customers rapidly migrate S/4HANA systems to Private Cloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP, SAP RISE), they often choose an "as-is" migration. This decouples functional upgrades from the technical move, significantly compressing project duration and minimizing the need for extensive regression testing.

While traditional methods like HANA Backup/Restore (only viable for small databases) and HANA System Replication (HSR) are common, HSR presents critical challenges in a cloud migration:

  1. Homogeneous Naming: HSR demands the same SID and Instance Number for source and target, which conflicts with new naming conventions often required on the cloud, especially in SAP RISE.
  2. Auxiliary Usage: Using the HA/DR focused HSR solution for a one-time copy complicates the reconfiguration of the target HA/DR setup after cutover.
  3. Cutover Time: Breaking replication and re-establishing HA/DR post-cutover adds additional downtime.

HANA Tenant Copy: The Migration Alternative

HANA Tenant Copy is an ECS-supported approach that addresses these HSR limitations. While operationally somewhat to HSR, it differs conceptually and is suitable for migrating systems that require a SID change on the target. It creates an isolated replica of any tenant, requiring mostly that the target HANA version is same or higher than the source.

üîêSecuring the Tenant Copy Data Transfer (SSL)

A crucial security requirement is ensuring the data transfer between source and target is secure via SSL. Most Basis teams overlook this, thinking it requires external certificates. However, we can easily achieve this using the inbuilt certificate every HANA DB already possesses. In this post, we are going to see how we can 

Pre-Requisite ‚Äì

Set-up below parameters on Source and Target Database. Also, log mode should be normal for Tenant Copy to work.

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] ssl must be set to systempki
  • [system_replication_communication] enable_ssl must be set to on

On Source DB only ‚Äì

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] listeninterface must be set to .global

(A DB restart would be required in most cases).

When establishing connectivity between the Source and Target databases, the following port ranges should be opened. If security policies are restrictive, specific ports based on the instance number can be opened instead.

Port Range

Purpose

3XXXX

Mandatory. SQL port of the HANA Index Server. Main port used by application servers and SQL clients to connect to the HANA DB.

4XXXX

Mandatory. Internal HANA communication port, used heavily for system replication (HSR) and Tenant Copy.

5XXXX

Recommended. Used by nameserver, web dispatcher‚Äìrelated connections, and certain internal HA/scale-out services. Helps hosts exchange availability and topology information.

 Step-by-Step Secure Tenant Copy Execution

Step1: Create a dummy Tenant Database (ABC) on the source system to serve as a copy template. (Note: For actual migration, use the existing S/4HANA connected database, skipping this creation step.)

Take backup of the source database so that Tenant copy can be initiated (same restriction as that of HSR)

Step 2: On the target HANA system, create a Personal Security Environment (PSE) (e.g., TenantCopy) and assign its purpose as Database Replication.

Step 3: On the source HANA system, navigate to the $SECUDIR directory and copy the content of the root certificate, which is typically named clientpki_SYSTEMDB.cer. (Important: Use the SYSTEMDB certificate, not the tenant's certificate like clientpki_ABC.cer).

Step 4: Using the copied certificate content, create a new certificate entity within the target HANA database.

Step 5 : On the target system, execute the necessary SQL query to identify and note the certificate number assigned to the new certificate created in Step 4.

Step 6 : Add the certificate identified in Step 5 to the PSE created in Step 2 on the target system.

Step 7: Verify the successful addition by querying the PSE_CERTIFICATE view on the target HANA system.

Step 8: On the target system, create a Credential for the source database, using the Source SYSTEMDB password for authentication.

Step 9: On the Target, initiate the Replica Query to copy the source tenant (ABC) to the target tenant (XYZ). (In a real scenario, you would first stop the target Application Server, drop the existing S/4HANA target DB, and then create the new tenant with the exact required target name.).

Step 10 : Monitor the replication from the Target. Replication is active when the status shows Target_Active_Status = ‚ÄúYes‚Äù. The replication is complete when the DB status in M_DATABASE changes to ACTIVE REPLICA, indicating the target is ready for finalization.

 

Step 11: On the target system, issue the Finalize Replica Query to bring the target database online. (Crucially, before executing the finalization, stop the source S/4HANA system to mark the business downtime start.)

After finalization, perform follow-up activities, including reconfiguring the HDBUSERSTORE and starting the target S/4HANA application system.

References ‚Äì

Copying and Moving Tenant Databases | SAP Help Portal

Copy or Move Tenants Within System Replication | SAP Help Portal

 

Best Regards,

Javed Alam

SAP BASIS Technical Architect

entry.title: When duct tape isn't architecture: Why your SQL-based inventory workaround is holding you back
entry.content:
As enterprise architects, our job isn't just to set up systems. It's to build future-proof, resilient, and valuable IT landscapes. In retail today, the biggest challenge is creating a seamless omnichannel experience. Customers expect to see in-store availability online, get items ordered in-store delivered to their homes, and return products wherever it's most convenient for them.

But many of these initiatives fail because of a fundamental architectural flaw: scattered inventory data. In the past, this was often patched up with a workaround that just kind of... happened: a SQL Server-based "Central Inventory" database. It acted as a bridge to painstakingly sync inventory between two ERP systems and the e-shop. But what was once a necessary evil is now, in the age of SAP S/4HANA and SAP CAR, just technical debt that kills agility and sustainability.

The Foundation: POSDTA as the Single Source of Truth

The foundation for any successful omnichannel strategy is a single, reliable source of truth for all transactional data. This is exactly where SAP CAR's POS Data Transfer and Audit (POSDTA) module comes in. It's so much more than just a tool for collecting sales receipts. POSDTA is the central hub that consolidates, validates, and harmonizes sales and returns data from all channels in real-time‚Äîfrom the in-store cash register to mobile POS devices and the e-commerce backend.

From an architectural standpoint, we're not just fixing data inconsistencies; we're paying off technical debt. Replacing the old central inventory solution with a standardized process within our SAP landscape is also a move toward IT sustainability. We're cutting down on complexity, shutting down fragile interfaces, and reducing the energy and maintenance needed to run redundant systems.

The Game-Changer: OAA as the Brains and Sustainability Layer

Building on this solid foundation of real-time inventory data is Omnichannel Article Availability (OAA). OAA is the intelligence that turns raw data into promises you can keep to your customers.

Without the precise, centralized inventory info from POSDTA, OAA would be flying blind. But with this foundation, OAA can truly shine:

  1. Reliable Availability Info: OAA provides a real-time, accurate answer to the question, "Where is this item available?" and feeds that info to the webshop or customer app. The result: no more disappointed customers due to incorrect stock levels.
  2. Smart and Sustainable Sourcing: When an online order comes in, OAA uses configurable rules to decide the most efficient place to ship it from. This has a huge environmental and economic sustainability impact. Instead of shipping every item from a central warehouse across the country, OAA enables ship-from-store from the nearest location. This shortens delivery routes, cuts CO2 emissions, and makes better use of the stock you already have. It helps reduce overstock and subsequent markdowns‚Äîa direct win against waste.

The Bottom Line for Our Architecture Strategy

Choosing to centralize inventory in SAP CAR isn't just a technical migration. It's a forward-thinking architectural decision. We're replacing a reactive, makeshift solution with a robust, scalable foundation (POSDTA) that allows us to build valuable and sustainable services (OAA). We're investing in real-time capabilities, simplifying our IT landscape, and creating the agility that tomorrow's fashion business demands‚Äîall in an economically and environmentally responsible way.

entry.title: How to Spot Real Opportunities to Modernize During an SAP Migration
entry.content:
Every time a company prepares for an SAP migration, the same idea appears on the whiteboard. 

‚ÄúThis is the ideal moment to rethink the architecture.‚Äù 

It makes sense conceptually: 

You are already revisiting integrations, touching data, updating custom logic, revalidating processes, and reorganizing environments. On paper, it feels like a natural opportunity to fix old decisions and build a stronger foundation for the next decade. 

But in real life, migrations do not happen on paper. They happen inside organizations with limited bandwidth, tight deadlines, pressure to stay within support, and a long list of technical tasks that cannot slip. 

The truth is that modernization during an SAP migration is possible, but it only works under specific conditions. And knowing how to recognize those moments is what separates a smooth migration from one that collapses under its own ambition. 

This article walks through how to identify true modernization opportunities without transforming your migration into a second battle your team cannot afford. 

 1. Greenfield opens the door, Brownfield narrows it 

One of the clearest signals comes from the migration approach itself. 

A Greenfield migration naturally creates space for modernization. Starting fresh means you can adopt clean core, redesign integration patterns, remove historical complexity and rethink how the business should operate. Everything is already being rebuilt, so it makes sense to align the architecture to modern practices. 

Brownfield and Bluefield migrations are different. They carry history, decisions and technical debt. Many teams arrive at this point after twenty years of enhancements, quick fixes, interfaces built under pressure and custom logic created for business requirements that no longer exist. In these scenarios, trying to modernize everything at once becomes risky and expensive. 

This does not mean modernization is impossible in Brownfield. It simply means it must be selective and realistic. 

 2. Bandwidth determines the limits of modernization 

This was one of the strongest insights from practitioners. 
SAP migrations already stretch teams in every direction. 

People need to remediate data, rewrite custom logic to fit the new data model, validate thousands of test cases, redesign integrations, coordinate freeze periods, handle cutover planning and support simultaneous environments for months. 

If the organization does not explicitly provide more time, more people or more budget, modernization becomes impossible. Teams cannot fight two battles at the same time. 

A common mistake is assuming modernization will ‚Äúfit naturally‚Äù inside existing migration tasks. It rarely does. If bandwidth is already consumed, modernization attempts create delays, testing failures and scope explosions. 

The best signal that modernization fits is simple. 
Leadership commits resources, not only expectations. 

 3. Look for overlap: modernization that complements migration work 

Even in high-pressure migrations, there are areas where modernization aligns perfectly with what the team must do anyway. These are the opportunities that experienced teams always look for. 

For example, when integrations must be revalidated, it becomes a natural moment to retire dead interfaces, remove duplicated endpoints or convert quick point-to-point connections into APIs. 

When master data is already being cleaned, it becomes easier to introduce governance rules and standard naming conventions. When reports need to be rebuilt, it creates the perfect window to simplify the pipeline or remove outdated transformations. 

These improvements don‚Äôt create a separate project within the migration. They sit on top of what the team is already doing, and they reduce risk instead of adding to it 

 4. Evaluate the real pain of legacy architecture 

The strongest indicator is the level of pain the current architecture is creating. 

If legacy integrations block new requirements, if custom objects break frequently, if reporting pipelines require constant maintenance or if data quality issues multiply every year, delaying modernization will only increase the cost. 

In those cases, the migration becomes a natural trigger. It is not just a modernization opportunity. It becomes a modernization obligation. 

On the other hand, if the architecture works well, even if it is not perfect, forcing a redesign during a migration can create unnecessary instability. 

The right moment is when the cost of doing nothing exceeds the effort of doing something. 

 5. Use migration to prepare modernization, not to overload the project 

During migration, focus on simplifying, cleaning and standardizing the areas the project already touches. After go-live, launch a dedicated modernization phase with its own scope, timeline and budget. 

This approach keeps the migration stable and predictable, while still creating the foundation for deeper improvements. 

Companies that follow this model often report smoother go-lives and faster modernization later, because the heavy work of cleaning and reorganizing was already done during the migration. 

The bottom line 

SAP migrations can absolutely create opportunities to modernize architecture. 
But the opportunity is not automatic. It appears only when certain conditions align. 

  • Greenfield makes modernization easier.  
  •  Brownfield requires discipline and realism.  
  •  Bandwidth defines the limits. 
  •  Overlap with existing tasks creates safe wins. 
  •  And the pain of legacy architecture determines urgency. 

The best modernization moments are the ones that come naturally from the migration itself. The best long-term transformations happen once the system is live and stable. 

Knowing how to distinguish both is what makes an SAP migration successful.

entry.title: How to Enhance Sales Order Item Processing in SAP: Tabstrip UI + Popup Quantity Editing
entry.content:
Building a Module Pool Program with Tab Strip, Popup Dialog, and Quantity Update in SAP ABAP 

Introduction 

In this post, we will look at how to build an SAP ABAP Module Pool application that displays Sales Order item details, opens a popup for editing quantities, and updates the values back to the main screen. 

 This requirement is common in logistics applications where users need to review and adjust quantities before posting follow-up processes. 

Business Requirement: 

  1. Display Sales Order Item Details using Tab Strip. 
  2. Provide two buttons: ADD SA and CANCEL. 
  3. On ADD SA ‚Üí show popup with first 5 items. 
  4. Quantity is editable. 
  5. Popup has OK and CANCEL. 
  6. OK updates quantity back in main table. 
  7. CANCEL closes popup without change. 

 Technical Components: 

- Module Pool 

- Screens 0100 and 0200 

- Table Controls 

- Tab Strip 

- PBO & PAI modules 

- PF-STATUS 

- Internal tables 

Screen Designs 

Screen 100 ‚Äì Main Screen 

Sales Order input field 

Tab Strip containing VBAP fields: 

  • POSNR 
  • MATNR 
  • CHARG 
  • ARKTX 
  • KWMENG 
  • WERKS, etc. 

Table Control (TABLE1) 

Buttons: 

GET 

ADD SA 

CANCEL 

Screen 200 ‚Äì Popup Screen 

Modal popup 

Table Control (TABLE2) with: 

5 items only 

Editable Qty (KWMENG) 

Buttons: 

OK 

CANCEL 

Application Flow 

1Ô∏è User enters Sales Order number 

2Ô∏è Presses ‚ÄúGET‚Äù 

‚Üí VBAP data retrieved 

‚Üí Items appear on main screen 

3Ô∏è User clicks ‚ÄúADD SA‚Äù 

‚Üí Popup opens 

‚Üí User edits quantity 

4Ô∏è User clicks ‚ÄúOK‚Äù 

‚Üí Updated values transferred back 

‚Üí Main screen refreshed 

5Ô∏è User clicks ‚ÄúCANCEL‚Äù 

‚Üí Popup closes without changes 

Key ABAP Logic Implementation 

  1. Reading Sales Order Item Data 
SELECT vbeln posnr matnr charg arktx 

       kwmeng werks lgort vstel 

  FROM vbap 
  INTO TABLE lt_vbap 
  WHERE vbeln = gv_vbeln.

2. Passing First 5 Items to Popup 

lt_vbap1 = lt_vbap. 

DELETE lt_vbap1 FROM 6. "Keep only first 5 items

3.Updating Quantities Back in Main Screen 

LOOP AT lt_vbap1 INTO ls_vbap1. 

  READ TABLE lt_vbap INTO ls_vbap WITH KEY posnr = ls_vbap1-posnr. 

  IF sy-subrc = 0. 

    ls_vbap-kwmeng = ls_vbap1-kwmeng. 

    MODIFY lt_vbap FROM ls_vbap INDEX sy-tabix. 

  ENDIF. 

ENDLOOP.

4.Handling Table Control Updates 

MODULE read_data INPUT. 

  MODIFY lt_vbap1 FROM ls_vbap1 INDEX table2-current_line. 

ENDMODULE.

 Conclusion 

This Module Pool program demonstrates: 

Effective use of classic SAP GUI dialog programming 

Leveraging Table Controls and Popup Screens 

Clean user-driven quantity update process 

Practical design for logistics screens 

This module pool program demonstrates flexible SAP GUI programming using popups, table controls, and classic PAI/PBO logic. 

REPORT ZSALESITEM_DATA_TASK. 
 
TABLES:VBAP. 
 
TYPES:BEGIN OF TY R _VBAP, 
     VBELN TYPE VBAP-VBELN, 
     POSNR TYPE VBAP-POSNR, 
     MATNR TYPE VBAP-MATNR, 
     CHARG TYPE VBAP-CHARG, 
     ARKTX TYPE VBAP-ARKTX, 
     KWMENG TYPE VBAP-KWMENG, 
     WERKS TYPE VBAP-WERKS, 
     LGORT TYPE VBAP-LGORT, 
     VSTEL TYPE VBAP-VSTEL, 
 END OF TY_VBAP. 
 
 
DATA: LT_VBAP TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_VBAP, 
     LS_VBAP TYPE ty_VBAP, 
 
     LT_VBAP1 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF TY_VBAP, 
     LS_VBAP1 TYPE TY_VBAP. 
 
CONTROLS: TABLE1 TYPE TABLEVIEW USING SCREEN 0100. 
CONTROLS: TABLE2 TYPE TABLEVIEW USING SCREEN 0200. 
 
START-OF-SELECTION. 
CALL SCREEN 100. 
call screen 200. 
 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0100  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE user_command_0100 INPUT. 
 
 CASE SY-UCOMM. 
   WHEN 'GET'. 
data LV_VBELN type vbap-vbeln. 
     SELECT POSNR MATNR 
            CHARG ARKTX 
            KWMENG WERKS 
            LGORT VSTEL  FROM VBAP INTO  CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE LT_VBAP 
      WHERE VBELN = LV_VBELN. 
   SORT lt_vbap BY vbeln. 
     WHEN 'EXIT'. 
       LEAVE PROGRAM. 
 
*      // Pop up 
   WHEN 'ADD'. 
     CALL SCREEN 200 STARTING AT 10 5 
     ENDING AT 100 10. 
 
 
 ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  STATUS_0200  OUTPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE status_0200 OUTPUT. 
 SET PF-STATUS 'STATUS'. 
  CASE sy-ucomm. 
     WHEN 'ENTER'. 
     CALL  SCREEN 100. 
   WHEN 'CANCEL'. 
     CALL SCREEN 100. 
 
*  SET TITLEBAR 'xxx'. 
 ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0200  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE user_command_0200 INPUT. 
 CASE sy-ucomm. 
 WHEN 'ENTER'. 
LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO ls_vbap ." where posnr = lv_posnr.  "kwmeng <> ls_vbap-kwmeng. 
       DATA(lv_index) = sy-tabix. 
 
   LOOP AT lt_vbap1 INTO ls_vbap1  where posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
         if sy-subrc = 0. 
         ls_vbap-KWMENG = ls_vbap1-kwmeng. 
         MODIFY lt_vbap FROM ls_vbap INDEX lv_index  TRANSPORTING KWMENG. 
       ENDIF. 
     ENDLOOP. 
     ENDLOOP. 
     LEAVE to SCREEN 0. 
 
   WHEN 'EXIT'. 
     LEAVE PROGRAM. 
 
     ENDCASE. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  READ_DATA  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE read_data INPUT. 
modify lt_vbap1 from ls_vbap1 index table2-current_line. 
 
ENDMODULE. 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*&      Module  FIELD-SEL  INPUT 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*       text 
*----------------------------------------------------------------------* 
MODULE field-sel INPUT. 
 
 READ TABLE LT_VBAP INTO LS_VBAP INDEX TABLE1-CURRENT_LINE. 
 IF SY-SUBRC = 0. 
   LS_VBAP1 = LS_VBAP. 
   APPEND LS_VBAP1 TO LT_VBAP1. 
   ENDIF. 
 
ENDMODULE.

entry.title: Untangling the Mess: A Practical Guide to Clean Core Success
entry.content:
Every system is perfectly designed to get the result that it does.  -  W. Edwards Deming.

Background

Do you feel that your system landscape is held together by duct tape and a hope and a prayer?

You are worried that your landscape is meeting today‚Äôs needs, but it isn‚Äôt ready to adapt to new technologies and face tomorrow‚Äôs challenges. As an IT expert, you are not only worried about the sprawl of interconnected (various on-prem and cloud) applications, but you are also worried about poor-quality data and legacy processes. Legacy business processes were designed around the capabilities of applications to such an extent that untangling them seems overwhelming.

How can we get out of this vicious cycle?

Experts often gush out obvious advice like 1) Reduce technical debt, 2) standardize process, and 3) keep data clean, like people maintaining the system don‚Äôt already know that. The strategy is clear, but the influence of the status quo is strong, and overcoming this challenge will require time and a cultural shift.

You can follow the SAP Clean Core methodology, but establishing strong governance to implement the obvious advice listed above won‚Äôt make a measurable difference in any of these activities.

What is ‚ÄúCore‚Äù anyway?

There are five core components that can describe how the business works in the context of an ERP  

  • Business Process: E2E processes describe how the business creates value. Processes are executed by users using applications and by creating/updating/analyzing data. Essentially, these processes facilitate the flow of money, materials, people, and information.
  • Applications and its extensions: Manages processes by applying rules, logic, business flow, preferences and policies.
  • Data: (in various applications): Enterprise structure, Master data, transaction data, unstructured data, etc.
  • Integrations: Connecting internal and external applications where data/information is exchanged
  • Operations: IT operations to manage platforms, upgrades, patches, versions etc.

Figure 1. Interconnected Core and it's key components

 

All these system components work together to ensure that the business functions smoothly. This system is often perfectly designed to achieve the results it does to support today‚Äôs business. i.e. "Status quo that works, why change?"  This argument, this complacency, is your number one inhibitor to being ready for tomorrow's opportunities.

Several factors contributed to a complex landscape.

  1. Over the years, as business processes and technology have evolved at different paces, interdependency has continued to increase, resulting in the landscape you see today.
  2. More peripheral applications are being used to complete/automate End-to-End business processes that resulted in multiple integration patterns that link processes, data and applications.
  3. Over the years, various new technologies were implemented through many projects without retrofitting existing applications, which resulted in a sprawl that you see today

Clean Core Principles

The clean core principles help ensure customers‚Äô business-critical systems remain agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovations that drive business forward. By adopting standard processes that incorporate stable extensions and integrations, the clean core principles enable customers to flexibly adapt to changing business requirements and adopt new capabilities.

There are five key clean core principles

Figure 2 - Clean Core Principles

How to implement Clean Core culture?

Defending clean core via governance is an outdated approach. You will need to establish a culture that encourages new behaviour patterns, monitor behaviour systematically and periodically and finally establish strong governance practices.

1. Establish a clean core culture (deter old practices):

  • Everybody wins, or nobody wins. Get your leaders in each domain to acknowledge the interconnectedness of the core components. Create a culture where everyone understands that you are in the same boat; it‚Äôs not a responsibility of a single department to maintain the core. Working on one or two components and ignoring others will be futile.
    • How: Leadership, Organization change management, training
  • Showcase what good looks like: Whatever project you are working on, ensure that all project leads, solution experts, and partners own all clean core dimensions (Process, Data, Integration, Extension, and operations). Demonstrating small success early goes a long way. Success breeds success.
    • How: Utilize SAP Signavio (clean core business processes), SAP Extensibility and Integration methodology, etc.
  • Education: Continuous education similar to what we do for ‚ÄúEthics‚Äù, ‚ÄúSecurity‚Äù, etc., is required. Understanding and promoting clean code should be ingrained in the company culture like an honour code.
    • How: SAP learning - Clean Core approach, Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

2 Detect:

Continuously monitor and measure early signs of infractions or a return to old behaviours. Individual infractions should be addressed quickly.

  • Continuous monitoring: Monitor deviations from clean core principles in real-time. The RISE with SAP Dashboard provides all the data you need to take action before it becomes too severe. Information gathered here is based on what‚Äôs actually happening in the system. Utilize this information from these tools to find behaviours that are working against clean core principles. e.g. Why are we not seeing an upward trend in the number of APIs being used? Or a reduction in the Level D extension?
    • How: RISE Dashboard in Cloud ALM, ATC Exception
  • Continuous measurement: Measure the maturity of various clean core dimensions, including self-assessment for each dimension. When this is done together for all five dimensions, it fosters healthy debate about interconnectedness, e.g., ‚Äòoverly complex business rules result in fragmented processes with redundant extensions and extra integrations.‚Äô Each quarter, measure your score and implement smaller improvements.
    • How: Clean Core KPI assessment

3. Defend:

If you follow the above two steps correctly, the efforts to defend decrease.

  • Governance: This is obvious, but creative consultants always find ways to justify their exceptions. Often, the first exceptions are benign, like a Trojan horse; they start small, and once you are hooked on an exception, you will need to build more complex enhancements and integrations to support your initial move. You will need to have a savvy ‚Äúconsigliere‚Äù in the governance body who can see two steps ahead. Often, these governance efforts focus on the project schedule and budget, but the amount of technical debt and process debt incurred during the project often goes unnoticed. We all have heard the phrase ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs focus on go-live, we will fix data/process/code later,‚Äù; and sadly, later never arrives. In essence, the governance structure must overcome the legacy block of focusing solely on schedule and cost to remain relevant in the clean core era.
    • How: Implement the Solution Standardization Board (SSB) or equivalent with the folks who can see through technical debt and process debt that tries to sneak in
  • Incentives/Penalties: Utilize a clean core scorecard to approve future funding, initiatives, and projects. Providing incentives (funding) for process standardization and penalties (budget control) for enhancement often works.
    • How: Clean core measurements, Portfolio Management. Outcome management, Value Management

Conclusion

Over the years, as business processes and technology have evolved at different paces, interdependency has continued to increase, resulting in the (process, application, data, technology) landscape you see today. This is all managed by a small group that will resist all changes, not because they don‚Äôt want to change, but more often because they understand the fragility of the current architecture and how precarious, rushed transformations can be.

Deter, Detect and Defend mindset can help an organization implement clean core principles during a transformation project. This approach provides a fighting chance that the clean core mindset will survive beyond the current focused project. The organization needs to ensure that the ‚Äúclean core‚Äù light is shining bright and there are no dark corners where one-off processes/customization are being worked on.

Complacency with the 'status quo' is not an option. Left unattended, system complexity will continue to grow. The best way to start a clean core journey was 20 years ago; the second best time is today!

Additional References:

  1. Clean core extensibility White paper
  2. Extend SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on premise with ABAP based extensions
  3. Learning journey ‚ÄúAcquiring Core ABAP Skills‚Äù
  4. Learning journey ‚ÄúManaging Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  5. Learning journey ‚ÄúPracticing Clean Core Extensibility For SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äù
  6. SAP Business Accelerator Hub

entry.title: Re: APP run proposal error
entry.content:
Hello @MdDilshad_Khan67 ,

I could think of below possibilities. Please verify.

 

CauseSymptomsWhere to CheckSolution
1. Errors in ProposalProposal released but no green lightF110 ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí Proposal ‚Üí Proposal LogFix errors (payment block, missing bank details, no open items, payment method missing), then regenerate proposal
2. ‚ÄúStart Immediately‚Äù not selectedProposal job stuck in released statusF110 ‚Üí Proposal tabTick Start Immediately and rerun proposal
3. Background Job stuck or cancelledProposal not processedSM37 ‚Üí Job F110*If cancelled ‚Üí fix issue & rerun; If stuck ‚Üí execute again
4. Old proposal existsSystem reuses old proposal, not generating newF110 ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí ProposalDelete existing proposal, then create new proposal
5. Wrong Run Date / Identification IDSystem shows proposal released but cannot continueF110 ‚Üí Run Date / IdentificationChange Run Date or Identification and rerun proposal
6. Payment block on vendor/invoiceNo items selected for paymentFB03 / FBL1NRemove payment block (FB02) if business allows
7. Missing payment method in Vendor MasterVendor excluded from proposalFK02 ‚Üí Company Code data ‚Üí Payment TransactionsAssign correct payment method
8. Missing House Bank / Payment Method ConfigProposal generated with warnings but no payment run possibleOBVCU / FBZPMaintain payment method in FBZP & house bank details
9. No open items fall within parametersProposal says released but nothing selectedF110 ‚Üí Display ProposalAdjust parameters (posting date, due date, company code, payment method)

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Best practice on Performance Forms for employees who...
entry.content:
Hello! Also not sure about best practice, but sharing another option to consider like Joanne.  When employees enter their new goals, we ask them to indicate which ones are for Role 1 and Role 2 (it's a special field with picklist options) for each goal. And, we ask that they weight the goals so they approximately equal the amount of time they have spent in each role. For example, if they were in Role 1 from Jan - May, they were there for about five months (aka 42% of the year) and in Role 2 from Jun - Dec, they were there for about seven months (58% of the year). So, they could round to have the goals weighted from Role 1 equal 40% and Role 2 equal 60%. 

Then at the end of the year (December) we launch the year-end review form that captures those details  and any comments they've added throughout the year. When they complete their self assessment it goes to their current manager who could then click on the "Get Feedback" button to send it to the previous manager or any other manager that may have had a dotted line to the employee throughout the year so that they can enter their feedback. When that former manager has added comments they send it back to the new manager who can complete the form.

entry.title: Re: MB5L
entry.content:
Hello @tarek07 ,

Try below fixes and let me know if it works.

SectionDetails (Full Content, Not Summarized)
Root CauseMB5L exports numbers using SAP decimal notation, while Excel interprets them using Windows regional settings. If SAP displays 2.000 but Excel expects 2,000 or vice-versa, Excel either drops decimals (2.000 ‚Üí 2) or multiplies by 1000 (2.000 ‚Üí 2000). This mismatch leads to inconsistent quantities and values in the spreadsheet after export.
Symptoms in ExcelSAP Value ‚Üí Excel Result ‚Üí Problem:‚Ä¢ 2.000 ‚Üí 2 ‚Üí Excel interprets ‚Äú.000‚Äù as decimals‚Ä¢ 2.000 ‚Üí 2000 ‚Üí Excel treats ‚Äú.‚Äù as thousand separator‚Ä¢ 1.234,56 ‚Üí 1234.56 ‚Üí Excel auto-converts locale format‚Ä¢ Quantities vary per material ‚Üí Mixed locale interpretations
Fix 1 ‚Äì Align SAP decimal notation with Windows/ExcelIn SAP: t-code SU3 ‚Üí Defaults ‚Üí Decimal Notation. Set the format to match Windows regional setting:‚Ä¢ 1,234.56 (US/UK)‚Ä¢ 1.234,56 (EU, LATAM)Re-run MB5L ‚Üí export again ‚Üí Excel now reads numbers correctly without modification.
Fix 2 ‚Äì Export as TXT and import via Excel (controlled import)Steps:1. In MB5L ‚Üí Export ‚Üí Local File ‚Üí TXT2. In Excel ‚Üí Data ‚Üí From Text/CSV ‚Üí Choose file3. Set Column Data Type = Text or Number properly. This prevents Excel from automatically changing decimal/thousand separators and preserves the exact SAP values.
Fix 3 ‚Äì Uniform formatting in SAP ALV GridIn the MB5L display: Go to Settings ‚Üí Format ‚Üí Uniform Formatting. This forces SAP to output consistent, locale-neutral numeric formats when exporting, reducing misinterpretation by Excel.
Fix 4 ‚Äì Force Excel to treat columns as text before openingBefore opening the file:‚Ä¢ Format relevant Excel columns as Text OR‚Ä¢ Use Excel: Data ‚Üí Get Data ‚Üí From Text/CSV (never double-click the file)<br. This prevents Excel from auto-converting 2.000 into 2 or 2000.
Best Practices for Accurate Exports‚Ä¢ Ensure SAP decimal notation = Windows number format (must match exactly).‚Ä¢ Prefer exporting as TXT, not XLS, for controlled import.‚Ä¢ Always use Data ‚Üí From Text/CSV to import.‚Ä¢ In ALV grid, enable Uniform Format before exporting.‚Ä¢ After import, cross-check at least one material‚Äôs quantity/value with SAP.
Quick Diagnostic TestCopy the value 2.000 from SAP and paste into Excel:‚Ä¢ If Excel shows 2, the decimal notation mismatch is confirmed.‚Ä¢ If Excel shows 2000, the thousand separator mismatch is confirmed.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Internal Career Job Posting Search for Location
entry.content:
We have been using the Recruiting module for years and just started using EC earlier this year. Ever since the implementation of EC (including position management) the search functionality for location has not worked on the internal careers site. The jobs don't display the location either, so it's really difficult for employees to find jobs to apply to that are at their location. 

Our tech support have told us that it pulls in from the Department field (position management), which is for the manager's org unit only and that we need to start populating the location field there, as well as create (and maintain) a custom business rule to map the postal code for each location, so that the jobs can be searched on the internal careers site. 

We have a couple of concerns with this approach.

  • First, we want it to display the location of the job requisition/position instead of the manager's Department. Sometimes managers who sit in one location have employees from various locations reporting to them and they want to recruit for a job at a specific location that is different than their own.
  • Second, this would be a lot more maintenance for our HR team to maintain a new field on the Department object, as well as our IT team would need to maintain the business rule each time a new location is added. 

Plus, it just seems odd that it would pull from the manager's Department instead of from the job requisition itself. 

Do you have any suggestions on how we can allow employees to search for jobs by location on the internal careers site?

Thanks!

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM
  • /SCWM/LM_ACTIVITY
  • /SCWM/LM_ELS
  • /SCWM/LM_EXCEPTION_CODES
  • /SCWM/LM_EXTERNAL_PROCESS_STEPS
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING
  • /SCWM/LM_WHS_NUMBER
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_10
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_15

2. Activate Labor Management
Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Labor Management

3. Define External Process steps

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define External Process Steps

 

4. Assign External Process steps to warehouse Activity

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign External Process Step to Warehouse Activity

5.   Assign Planned Activity Areas

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign Planning Activity Areas

6. Define Number Range for Performance Document

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Number Range for Performance Document

7. Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

8. Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

  • Activate Change Documents for Processor

  • Activate Change Documents for Performance Document

  • Activate Change Documents for Time and Attendance

9. Define Processor Types

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Processor Types

10. Define Reporting Groups for Processors

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Reporting Groups for Processors

11. Define Work Categories

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Work Categories

12. Define Capacity Variants

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Define Capacity Variants

13. Maintain Shift Management Defaults

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Maintain Shift Management Defaults



14. Create a Processor

T.Code: /N/SCMB/PRR1

15. Assign User to BP created

16. Conditions for Engineered Labor Standards

T.code: /N/SCWM/LM_CE

17. Formula for Engineered Labor Standards

18. Determine Engineering Labor Standards

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Determine Engineered Labor Standards

Test :

Pre- requisites:
Create two deliveries and distribute them to EWM, ensuring each delivery has a different weight, one below 20 kg and one above 20 kg, to match the conditions we configured.

Let‚Äôs first take an example with a weight below 20 kg, execute it, and review the workload. After that, we‚Äôll do the same for a case above 20 kg.

Maintain Inbound Deliveries

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI

As you can see, the delivery mentioned above includes a handling unit weighing 4.400 kg. Let‚Äôs create the warehouse task for unloading and execute it through the RF screen to validate the processor‚Äôs performance.

Let‚Äôs create a warehouse Task using Monitor-

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI>> Inbound Delivery>>Follow on Functions>>Warehouse Task

By clicking ‚ÄúCreate,‚Äù the system generates a warehouse task to move the handling unit from the Door to the GR-ZONE (staging area). Next, let‚Äôs review the Warehouse Order for ‚ÄúLM Active.‚Äù As shown, the LM Active checkbox is enabled, indicating that Labor Management is activated for this step.

Now let‚Äôs execute the activity in RF screen
Path: Inbound>> Unloading>> Unload by Delivery

Upon scanning the HU, the system captures the start timestamp and initiates the timer to measure the total time taken by the associate or processor to complete the activity.

Once you scan the destination bin and confirm ‚ÄúYes‚Äù for Completely Unloaded, the timer stops. Now let‚Äôs review the workload in the monitor.

The screenshot above is from the workload monitor, which displays the execution details. As shown, the processor ‚ÄúNICK WILDE‚Äù executed the unloading task, with the recorded weight of 4.2 kg. The planned execution time is 5 minutes, which is a critical value derived from the condition and formula maintained in configuration steps 16 and 17.

The monitor also shows the actual execution details start and end timestamps, planned duration, and the actual duration taken by the processor. In this example, the processor took 7.467 minutes to complete the task, compared to the planned 5 minutes. Based on this variance, the system calculated the processor‚Äôs efficiency as 66.96%.

Now, let‚Äôs take another delivery with a weight of 42.200 kg and review how the system determines the planned execution time for unloading, using the same configuration rules from steps 16 and 17.

Let‚Äôs execute the step and find out the performance

After execution, the planned time is 7 minutes, calculated based on the configured formula. The actual duration recorded is 18.317 minutes, resulting in an efficiency of 38.22%, since the processor took significantly longer than the planned time.

Through these scenarios, we validated how SAP EWM Labor Management calculates planned, actual, and efficient metrics using condition-based formulas. By executing unloading tasks for deliveries below and above the 20 kg threshold, we observed how the system dynamically derives planned execution time and evaluates processor performance via RF-driven timestamps. Importantly, these calculations are not limited to weight alone any relevant operational parameter (such as quantity, HU type, product group, packaging material, distance, activity type, or process step) can be incorporated into the condition and formula framework.

This flexibility allows organizations to tailor labor standards to real-world warehouse processes. Overall, these examples demonstrate how workload monitoring offers clear visibility into performance, highlights gaps between planned and actual durations, and enables data-driven optimization of warehouse efficiency in SAP EWM.

entry.title: Re: Copy functionality in AFC
entry.content:
Hello @JFPC ,

Try below options.

 

TopicFull Details (Not Summarized)
Short AnswerYES ‚Äî you can reuse your AFC closing template from Test for Production. NO ‚Äî you do not redo everything manually. Templates are NOT transported using SAP transports. Instead, AFC provides built-in ‚ÄúExport / Import‚Äù functions for templates, task lists, calendars, and configuration.
How AFC WorksAFC is not transported via SAP transports (like customizing). It is a standalone cloud tenant that connects to multiple backend systems (Test, Dev, Prod). Templates live in the AFC tenant. Backend S/4 systems are only used to execute tasks. Templates are not dependent on a specific S/4 system. You can import ‚Üí validate ‚Üí activate templates per connected system. This is why copy/export/import tools exist.
Option 1: Export / Import Template (Recommended)In Test System: 1) Go to Closing Structure ‚Üí Templates, 2) Select the template, 3) Export Template (generates a JSON file). In Production System: 1) Go to Closing Structure ‚Üí Templates, 2) Choose Import Template, 3) Upload the exported file, 4) Reassign company codes, systems, scheduling rules, and variants as needed. This is SAP‚Äôs recommended method.
Option 2: Duplicate Template Inside AFC and Change System AssignmentSteps: 1) In AFC, go to Templates, 2) Choose Copy / Duplicate, 3) Change System Assignment from TEST ‚Üí PRD, 4) Revalidate task dependencies. Works if you have the same org structure, same task library, and same company codes in PROD.
Option 3: Use AFC Content LifecycleIf AFC version supports it (2023+ features), use Content Lifecycle Management to move templates, task lists, variants, schedules, orchestrations. This is the enterprise-grade approach for customers with large AFC environments.
What Does NOT Work‚ùå Transporting configuration via STMS or customizing transports. ‚ùå Copying directly inside S/4. ‚ùå Re-creating tasks manually in PROD without AFC import. ‚ùå Migration Cockpit (irrelevant for AFC). AFC templates live in AFC tenant and are moved via AFC tools only.
What Needs Adjustment After ImportAfter importing the template into PROD, you must check or adjust: company codes (mapping Test ‚Üí Prod), factory calendars (Prod may differ), task scheduling offsets (if Prod closing calendar is different), user assignments (Prod users differ), authorizations for executors. Structure is identical, but assignments require validation.
Final RecommendationBuild and test the template in Test. Export it when Test is approved. Import into Production once the system is connected. Validate tasks ‚Üí Generate closing task list ‚Üí Activate. This prevents days of rework and ensures consistent closing processes across Test and Production.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: New Security Optimization Service for Cloud Identity Services (CQC SOS for CIS)
entry.content:
Security is no longer optional‚Äîit‚Äôs the backbone of digital trust and business continuity.

The SAP Security Optimization Service (SOS) is designed to analyze, verify, and improve the security of your SAP system by identifying potential security risks and providing recommendations to mitigate these risks within the assessed systems. 

There are many different SAP systems that can be analyzed with an SOS and can be referred from the CQC SOS Infosheet

üåüNew in CQC SOS: SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)!

What is CQC SOS for SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)?

  • SAP Cloud Identity Services are a group of services of SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), which enable you to integrate identity and access management between systems. 
  • Besides the CQC SOS for SAP BTP, which provides a security assessment of those security-relevant configurations and authorization assignments which are in the responsibility of the customer and focuses on reviewing the platform aspects, a new CQC SOS in the BTP realm is now available:  CQC SOS for CIS. 

The CQC SOS for CIS provides a security assessment structured in the following sections:

  • General Security Status for CIS - e.g. security aspects related to administrator user/system management like critical authorizations and MFA enforcement, the security alert and notification configuration etc.
  • Security Checks for Identity Authentication - e.g. application specific checks like assigned password policy, MFA,   Remember Me functionality etc.
  • Security Checks for Identity Provisioning - e.g. source and target system settings like logging and tracing for personal   and sensitive data, SSL Server Certificate Verification etc. 

üì©How to request a CQC service?

Create an incident under component SV-BO-REQ (SAP Note 1296527) or

Contact the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory team via our Customer Interaction Center (CIC)

‚òÅÔ∏èAs an SAP Enterprise Support or cloud customer:

Make use of the security and the enablement offerings provided by the SAP Enterprise Support Academy.

For more information on the topics discussed in this blog visit SAP Help Portal | SAP Online Help , Identity Authentication , Identity Provisioning

üîóStay connected

Want to stay up to date on our services? Join our SAP Cloud ALM & Cross-Solution Topics Value Map  and SAP Cloud Identity Services communities!
